elements.content: Water oxidation is the key step in both natural and artificial photosynthesis to capture solar energy for fuel production. The design of highly efficient and stable molecular catalysts for water oxidation based on nonprecious metals is still a great challenge. In this article, the electrocatalytic oxidation of water by Na­[(L4–)­CoIII], where L is a substituted tetraamido macrocyclic ligand, was investigated in aqueous solution (pH 7.0). We found that Na­[(L4–)­CoIII] is a stable and efficient homogeneous catalyst for electrocatalytic water oxidation with 380 mV onset overpotential in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.0). Both ligand- and metal-centered redox features are involved in the catalytic cycle. In this cycle, Na­[(L4–)­CoIII] was first oxidized to [(L2–)­CoIIIOH] via a ligand-centered proton-coupled electron transfer process in the presence of water. After further losing an electron and a proton, the resting state, [(L2–)­CoIIIOH], was converted to [(L2–)­CoIVO]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the B3LYP-D3­(BJ)/6-311++G­(2df,2p)//B3LYP/6-31+G­(d,p) level of theory confirmed the proposed catalytic cycle. According to both experimental and DFT results, phosphate-assisted water nucleophilic attack to [(L2–)­CoIVO] played a key role in O–O bond formation.
elements.clean_text: Water oxidation is the key step in both natural and artificial photosynthesis to capture solar energy for fuel production. The design of highly efficient and stable molecular catalysts for water oxidation based on nonprecious metals is still a great challenge. In this article, the electrocatalytic oxidation of water by Na[(L4-)CoIII], where L is a substituted tetraamido macrocyclic ligand, was investigated in aqueous solution (pH 7.0). We found that Na[(L4-)CoIII] is a stable and efficient homogeneous catalyst for electrocatalytic water oxidation with 380 mV onset overpotential in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.0). Both ligand- and metal-centered redox features are involved in the catalytic cycle. In this cycle, Na[(L4-)CoIII] was first oxidized to [(L2-)CoIIIOH] via a ligand-centered proton-coupled electron transfer process in the presence of water. After further losing an electron and a proton, the resting state, [(L2-)CoIIIOH], was converted to [(L2-)CoIVO]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the B3LYP-D3(BJ)/6-311++G(2df,2p)//B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) level of theory confirmed the proposed catalytic cycle. According to both experimental and DFT results, phosphate-assisted water nucleophilic attack to [(L2-)CoIVO] played a key role in O-O bond formation.

elements.content: Solar-to-fuel conversion chemistry is a highly active field in chemistry and material science due to the rising global energy demands and climate changes. Inspired by nature, artificial photosynthesis, where solar energy is employed to split H2O into O2 and H2, is deemed to be an attractive way to convert solar energy into fuels. Water oxidation (2H2O → O2 + 4e – + 4H+), which provides the necessary reducing equivalents for both hydrogen evolution and CO2 reduction, remains a bottleneck for solar-powered water splitting. Numerous molecular catalysts for water oxidation have been described, including robust and highly active ones that are based on second- and third-row transition metals, such as Ru and Ir. In contrast, the development of molecular water oxidation catalysts (WOCs) based on earth-abundant first-row transition metals that could operate under mild conditions (neutral pH) remains a challenge. Although examples based on Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu have been reported, most of these catalysts require a formal high oxidation state, such as Co­(IV), Fe­(V), Fe­(VI), and even Cu­(IV) to drive water oxidation. This led to relatively liable catalytic systems and strong dependence on the reaction conditions such as pH and type of buffer and oxidant, compared to Ru-based catalysts. Therefore, the rational design of robust and efficient molecular water oxidation catalysts based on earth-abundant first-row transition metals needs further exploration.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Solar-to-fuel conversion chemistry is a highly active field in chemistry and material science due to the rising global energy demands and climate changes. Inspired by nature, artificial photosynthesis, where solar energy is employed to split H2O into O2 and H2, is deemed to be an attractive way to convert solar energy into fuels. Water oxidation (2H2O → O2 + 4e - + 4H+), which provides the necessary reducing equivalents for both hydrogen evolution and CO2 reduction, remains a bottleneck for solar-powered water splitting. Numerous molecular catalysts for water oxidation have been described, including robust and highly active ones that are based on second- and third-row transition metals, such as Ru and Ir. In contrast, the development of molecular water oxidation catalysts (WOCs) based on earth-abundant first-row transition metals that could operate under mild conditions (neutral pH) remains a challenge. Although examples based on Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu have been reported, most of these catalysts require a formal high oxidation state, such as Co(IV), Fe(V), Fe(VI), and even Cu(IV) to drive water oxidation. This led to relatively liable catalytic systems and strong dependence on the reaction conditions such as pH and type of buffer and oxidant, compared to Ru-based catalysts. Therefore, the rational design of robust and efficient molecular water oxidation catalysts based on earth-abundant first-row transition metals needs further exploration.

elements.content: The intrinsic challenge of water oxidation catalysis is due to the multielectron catalytic process, which involved four steps of accumulative electron transfer. This requires the catalyst to reach a high formal oxidation state and thus increases the difficulty of keeping the catalyst live and homogeneous for a long time. In photosystem II (PSII), a Mn4Ca cluster in the oxygen evolution complex disperses the charges at multiple metal sites to evade the charge accumulated on a single metal center and avoid reaching a high oxidation state. To avoid charge accumulation, on the other hand, redox ligands were extensively used in metalloenzymatic and organometallic multielectron reactions owing to the synergistic ligand effect when a formal high oxidation state was reached. The latter strategy shows the possibility of tuning the reactivity and stability of high oxidation state intermediates by using a redox-active ligand relative to the metal center, particularly for single-site catalysis. Simple cobalt salts have been known to catalyze water oxidation since the 1980s; for example, the development of cobalt-based molecular WOCs was boosted after in situ generated cobalt-based WOC (Co-Pi) was reported by Nocera and co-workers. A series of cobalt complexes with different kinds of ligands such as corrole, polypyridine, salen, and porphyrin were applied for electro- or photocatalyzed water oxidation. However, a challenge for Co-based homogeneous catalyst development is the intrinsic instability of the high oxidation state intermediate from which the ligand was easily liberated and CoO x formed.

To avoid charge accumulation, on the other hand, redox ligands were extensively used in metalloenzymatic and organometallic multielectron reactions owing to the synergistic ligand effect when a formal high oxidation state was reached. The latter strategy shows the possibility of tuning the reactivity and stability of high oxidation state intermediates by using a redox-active ligand relative to the metal center, particularly for single-site catalysis. Simple cobalt salts have been known to catalyze water oxidation since the 1980s; for example, the development of cobalt-based molecular WOCs was boosted after in situ generated cobalt-based WOC (Co-Pi) was reported by Nocera and co-workers. A series of cobalt complexes with different kinds of ligands such as corrole, polypyridine, salen, and porphyrin were applied for electro- or photocatalyzed water oxidation. However, a challenge for Co-based homogeneous catalyst development is the intrinsic instability of the high oxidation state intermediate from which the ligand was easily liberated and CoO x  formed.

elements.content: In this contribution, we report a family of cobalt-based water oxidation catalysts supported by tetraamido macrocyclic ligands (TAML), where redox-active functionalities are incorporated at equatorial positions. These cobalt catalysts are capable of homogeneously electrocatalyzing water oxidation at pH 7, where the redox ligand facilitates the multielectron catalysis by promoting synergistic accumulative electron–proton transfer. This feature further illustrated that the ligand-centered redox process was equally important to the catalytic metal center for rational design of molecular catalyst for water oxidation.
elements.clean_text: In this contribution, we report a family of cobalt-based water oxidation catalysts supported by tetraamido macrocyclic ligands (TAML), where redox-active functionalities are incorporated at equatorial positions. These cobalt catalysts are capable of homogeneously electrocatalyzing water oxidation at pH 7, where the redox ligand facilitates the multielectron catalysis by promoting synergistic accumulative electron-proton transfer. This feature further illustrated that the ligand-centered redox process was equally important to the catalytic metal center for rational design of molecular catalyst for water oxidation.

elements.content: Redox-active ligands have long been recognized not only for the intriguing electronic structure of the resulting metal complexes but also for their role as electron reservoirs. o-Diphenylene­di­carboxamido (bpb2–) is a classic example of a redox-active ligand. shows the three possible redox forms of this ligand with o-diphenylene­dicarboxamido (bpb2–) as its most reduced form and o-dicarboxamido­semiquinonate (bpb•–) and o-benzoquinone­dicarboxamido (bpb0) as intermediate and the most oxidized form, respectively. TAML, developed by Collins and co-workers, is a derivative of the bpb2– ligand and is capable of stabilizing unusual formal high valent metal ions such as Co­(IV) and Fe­(V), which were usually proposed as key intermediates for water oxidation. Inspired by these pioneering works, as well as the redox properties of the bpb2–-type ligand, we selected a series complexes, Na­[(L1–3 4–)­CoIII] (), as model complexes to investigate the metal–ligand cooperation in water oxidation. Because both metal and ligand have variable oxidation state, in principle, the catalyst is more likely to reach a higher formal oxidation state and thus facilitate the water oxidation. To clearly understand the importance of the redox ligand, an analogue with a nonredox ligand, Na­[(L4 4–)­CoIII], was selected as a reference. Based on the above considerations, we have conducted the investigations presented as follows.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Redox-active ligands have long been recognized not only for the intriguing electronic structure of the resulting metal complexes but also for their role as electron reservoirs. o-Diphenylenedicarboxamido (bpb2-) is a classic example of a redox-active ligand.  shows the three possible redox forms of this ligand with o-diphenylenedicarboxamido (bpb2-) as its most reduced form and o-dicarboxamidosemiquinonate (bpb⋅-) and o-benzoquinonedicarboxamido (bpb0) as intermediate and the most oxidized form, respectively. TAML, developed by Collins and co-workers, is a derivative of the bpb2- ligand and is capable of stabilizing unusual formal high valent metal ions such as Co(IV) and Fe(V), which were usually proposed as key intermediates for water oxidation. Inspired by these pioneering works, as well as the redox properties of the bpb2--type ligand, we selected a series complexes, Na[(L1-3 4-)CoIII] (), as model complexes to investigate the metal-ligand cooperation in water oxidation. Because both metal and ligand have variable oxidation state, in principle, the catalyst is more likely to reach a higher formal oxidation state and thus facilitate the water oxidation. To clearly understand the importance of the redox ligand, an analogue with a nonredox ligand, Na[(L4 4-)CoIII], was selected as a reference. Based on the above considerations, we have conducted the investigations presented as follows.

elements.content: Ligands (H4L 1–4 ) listed in were synthesized through a modified literature procedure (the details are listed in the Supporting Information). The ligands were deprotonated by NaHMDS and coordinated to CoCl2 in THF under an argon atmosphere. The desired Co­(III) complexes were obtained under air exposure. The cobalt complexes are negatively charged, and the countercation is Na+. X-ray crystallography () showed that Co­(III) in the solid state is in a square-planar coordination sphere comprising four deprotonated N atoms of the ligand moiety, which is similar to the reported structure. These complexes were characterized by ESI-MS and 1H NMR. Typical paramagnetically shifted 1H NMR spectra of square planar CoIII (S = 1) systems (Figures S1–S7) were observed for these complexes. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation showed these Co­(III) complexes still adopt four coordination without an aqua in water, and the details are discussed below.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Characterization of Na[(L4-)CoIII]

Ligands (H4L 1-4 ) listed in  were synthesized through a modified literature procedure (the details are listed in the Supporting Information). The ligands were deprotonated by NaHMDS and coordinated to CoCl2 in THF under an argon atmosphere. The desired Co(III) complexes were obtained under air exposure. The cobalt complexes are negatively charged, and the countercation is Na+. X-ray crystallography () showed that Co(III) in the solid state is in a square-planar coordination sphere comprising four deprotonated N atoms of the ligand moiety, which is similar to the reported structure. These complexes were characterized by ESI-MS and 1H NMR. Typical paramagnetically shifted 1H NMR spectra of square planar CoIII (S = 1) systems (Figures S1-S7) were observed for these complexes. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation showed these Co(III) complexes still adopt four coordination without an aqua in water, and the details are discussed below.

elements.content: The electrochemical behaviors of Na­[(L4–)­CoIII] were investigated in 0.1 M phosphate buffer solution (PBS) at pH 7.0, and the results are listed in and illustrated in and Figures S8 and S9. shows a typical cyclic voltammogram (CV) i–E response of Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] and its variation with scan rates (i vs v 1/2). Two irreversible oxidation processes were observed at E p,a = 1.00 and 1.476 V (vs NHE), respectively. The latter wave has a greatly enhanced underlying current compared to the background (a, red line). The i ∼ v 1/2 graph in b showed that the first wave with E p,a = 1.00 V is independent of v 1/2, and the second wave with E p,a = 1.48 V is proportional to v 1/2, indicating that the first wave relates to a diffusion-controlled process and the second wave relates to a catalytic process. The onset potential for this catalytic process appears at ∼1.20 V vs NHE. In contrast to Na­[(L1–3 4–)­CoIII], the complex with the nonredox ligand, Na­[(L4 4–)­CoIII], only displayed a noncatalytic irreversible wave at 1.308 V vs NHE (a, blue dashed line).

Electrochemical Properties of Na[(L4-)CoIII] in Water at pH 7.0

Cyclic Voltammograms

The electrochemical behaviors of Na[(L4-)CoIII] were investigated in 0.1 M phosphate buffer solution (PBS) at pH 7.0, and the results are listed in  and illustrated in  and Figures S8 and S9.  shows a typical cyclic voltammogram (CV) i-E response of Na[(L1 4-)CoIII] and its variation with scan rates (i vs v 1/2). Two irreversible oxidation processes were observed at E p,a = 1.00 and 1.476 V (vs NHE), respectively. The latter wave has a greatly enhanced underlying current compared to the background (a, red line). The i ~ v 1/2 graph in b showed that the first wave with E p,a = 1.00 V is independent of v 1/2, and the second wave with E p,a = 1.48 V is proportional to v 1/2, indicating that the first wave relates to a diffusion-controlled process and the second wave relates to a catalytic process. The onset potential for this catalytic process appears at ~1.20 V vs NHE. In contrast to Na[(L1-3 4-)CoIII], the complex with the nonredox ligand, Na[(L4 4-)CoIII], only displayed a noncatalytic irreversible wave at 1.308 V vs NHE (a, blue dashed line).

elements.content: Oxygen evolution was confirmed by bulk electrolysis at +1.40 V (vs Ag/AgCl) on an ITO electrode with a large surface area (1 cm2), employing 1 mM Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] in phosphate buffer (pH 7.0). The oxygen formed in the solution was measured using a calibrated Ocean Optics FOXY probe (). The oxygen generated at the applied potential in the absence of catalyst was negligibly small, whereas with 1 mM Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] added, the catalytic current was sustained at a stable current density of 0.25 mA/cm2 (Figure S10). The dissolved O2 in the solution phase increased from 65 to 256 μM in 1 h with a Faraday efficiency greater than 90% for the O2 evolution, indicating that the catalytic wave observed in a is a water oxidation process with an onset overpotential of 380 mV.
elements.clean_text:
Confirmation of Oxygen Evolution

Oxygen evolution was confirmed by bulk electrolysis at +1.40 V (vs Ag/AgCl) on an ITO electrode with a large surface area (1 cm2), employing 1 mM Na[(L1 4-)CoIII] in phosphate buffer (pH 7.0). The oxygen formed in the solution was measured using a calibrated Ocean Optics FOXY probe (). The oxygen generated at the applied potential in the absence of catalyst was negligibly small, whereas with 1 mM Na[(L1 4-)CoIII] added, the catalytic current was sustained at a stable current density of 0.25 mA/cm2 (Figure S10). The dissolved O2 in the solution phase increased from 65 to 256 μM in 1 h with a Faraday efficiency greater than 90% for the O2 evolution, indicating that the catalytic wave observed in a is a water oxidation process with an onset overpotential of 380 mV.

elements.content: The distinguishment between homogeneous and heterogeneous WOCs has received particular concern with respect to the challenge of molecular catalyst stability. Given the fact that the robust and effective heterogeneous catalyst, CoO x , could be easily formed during catalysis from simple aqueous Co2+ or molecular precatalyst, we thus investigated the stability of Na­[(L4–)­CoIII] WOCs under electrocatalytic conditions. Over multiple CVs at GC and ITO electrode, there were insignificant changes in peak currents or wave shapes. Electrodes after multiple CVs gave no catalytic response in a fresh, cobalt-catalyst-free electrolyte at pH 7.0 (Figures S11 and S12). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) result showed no signal of CoO x formed on the ITO electrode after bulk electrolysis (Figure S13); SEM of the ITO surface topography also showed that no cobalt oxide precipitated during electrolysis (Figure S14). The electrochemical behaviors of Na­[(L4–)­CoIII] strongly rely on the ligand (Figure S8), which differs from the previously reported Co-Pi catalyst, which excludes the self-healing cobalt oxide catalysis. Taking these observations into account, the results provide strong evidence for the key role of structurally intact Na­[(L4–)­CoIII] in the electrocatalytic cycle, and a homogeneous catalytic process proceeded under the conditions used here, despite the difficulty to definitively exclude a colloid material.
elements.clean_text:
Proof for Homogeneous Catalysis

The distinguishment between homogeneous and heterogeneous WOCs has received particular concern with respect to the challenge of molecular catalyst stability. Given the fact that the robust and effective heterogeneous catalyst, CoO x , could be easily formed during catalysis from simple aqueous Co2+ or molecular precatalyst, we thus investigated the stability of Na[(L4-)CoIII] WOCs under electrocatalytic conditions. Over multiple CVs at GC and ITO electrode, there were insignificant changes in peak currents or wave shapes. Electrodes after multiple CVs gave no catalytic response in a fresh, cobalt-catalyst-free electrolyte at pH 7.0 (Figures S11 and S12). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) result showed no signal of CoO x  formed on the ITO electrode after bulk electrolysis (Figure S13); SEM of the ITO surface topography also showed that no cobalt oxide precipitated during electrolysis (Figure S14). The electrochemical behaviors of Na[(L4-)CoIII] strongly rely on the ligand (Figure S8), which differs from the previously reported Co-Pi catalyst, which excludes the self-healing cobalt oxide catalysis. Taking these observations into account, the results provide strong evidence for the key role of structurally intact Na[(L4-)CoIII] in the electrocatalytic cycle, and a homogeneous catalytic process proceeded under the conditions used here, despite the difficulty to definitively exclude a colloid material.

elements.content: The electrochemical behaviors of Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] at full pH range from 5 to 11 were carried out in 0.1 M phosphate buffer solutions (Figure S15), and the resulted E–pH diagram is shown in . As shown in the CV graph (), there are two irreversible oxidation waves at E p,a = 1.00 and 1.48 V (vs NHE) at pH 7.0. The first irreversible oxidation wave is pH-dependent from pH 5 to pH 9 with a slope of 30 mV/pH, and the slope became 59 mV at pH >9.0. Three lines of evidence indicate this oxidation wave proceeds as a ligand-centered proton-coupled oxidation of Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] to [(L1 2–)­CoIIIOH], as shown in and . At the 5 < pH < 9 range, it proceeds as shown in : ( L 4 − ) Co III + H 2 O → ( L 2 − ) Co III OH + 2 e − + H + and at pH >9, the oxidation wave occurred as shown in : ( L 4 − ) Co III + H 2 O → ( L 2 − ) Co III O − + 2 e − + 2 H +
elements.clean_text:
Ligand-Centered Proton-Coupled Electron Transfer

The electrochemical behaviors of Na[(L1 4-)CoIII] at full pH range from 5 to 11 were carried out in 0.1 M phosphate buffer solutions (Figure S15), and the resulted E-pH diagram is shown in . As shown in the CV graph (), there are two irreversible oxidation waves at E p,a = 1.00 and 1.48 V (vs NHE) at pH 7.0. The first irreversible oxidation wave is pH-dependent from pH 5 to pH 9 with a slope of 30 mV/pH, and the slope became 59 mV at pH >9.0. Three lines of evidence indicate this oxidation wave proceeds as a ligand-centered proton-coupled oxidation of Na[(L1 4-)CoIII] to [(L1 2-)CoIIIOH], as shown in  and . At the 5 < pH < 9 range, it proceeds as shown in : 1     (   L   4 -   )    Co   III   +   H   2   O →  (   L   2 -   )    Co   III   OH + 2   e   -   +   H   +     and at pH >9, the oxidation wave occurred as shown in : 2     (   L   4 -   )    Co   III   +   H   2   O →  (   L   2 -   )    Co   III     O   -   + 2   e   -   + 2   H   +

elements.content: First, the ligand is easier to be oxidized than the CoIII center of Na­[(L1–3 4–)­CoIII] in acetonitrile (ligand-centered oxidation). CVs of Na­[(L1–3 4–)­CoIII] complexes employed in this study displayed a reversible CoIII/II reduction wave at −1.06 to −1.23 V and two reversible one-electron transfer oxidation waves at 0.34 to 0.64 V and 0.84 to 0.94 V (vs Fc+/0) in CH3CN (), respectively. These two waves are in agreement with the reported o-diphenylene­dicarboxamido (bpb2–) ligated CoIII complex. The electrochemical behavior of the complex with nonredox ligand Na­[(L4 4–)­CoIII] () displayed only two waves at −1.46 and 0.80 V but without a reversible wave at 0.34 to 0.64 V. Because the electrochemically generated mono-oxidized species, namely, [(L1–3 3–)­CoIII], are stable in acetonitrile, the UV–vis spectra were recorded. [(L1 3–)­CoIII] species displayed intense new absorptions in the visible and near-infrared regions (596 and 746 nm) that are characteristic of (imino)­semiquinonato radical (bpb•–) (Figure S16). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum of this electrochemically generated mono-oxidized species in acetonitrile has an isotropic character with a g value of 1.997 (), indicating that the oxidation of [(L1–3 4–)­CoIII]− is ligand-centered, with the formation of the corresponding (imino)­semiquinonato organic radical (bpb•–). These results indicated that the reversible wave at 0.34 to 0.64 V (vs Fc+/0), which is strongly dependent on the substituents on the ligand, should be ascribed to the ligand-centered oxidation, whereas the wave at 0.84 to 0.94 V (vs Fc+/0) should be attributed to the oxidation of CoIII.

Because the electrochemically generated mono-oxidized species, namely, [(L1-3 3-)CoIII], are stable in acetonitrile, the UV-vis spectra were recorded. [(L1 3-)CoIII] species displayed intense new absorptions in the visible and near-infrared regions (596 and 746 nm) that are characteristic of (imino)semiquinonato radical (bpb⋅-) (Figure S16). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum of this electrochemically generated mono-oxidized species in acetonitrile has an isotropic character with a g value of 1.997 (), indicating that the oxidation of [(L1-3 4-)CoIII]- is ligand-centered, with the formation of the corresponding (imino)semiquinonato organic radical (bpb⋅-). These results indicated that the reversible wave at 0.34 to 0.64 V (vs Fc+/0), which is strongly dependent on the substituents on the ligand, should be ascribed to the ligand-centered oxidation, whereas the wave at 0.84 to 0.94 V (vs Fc+/0) should be attributed to the oxidation of CoIII.

elements.content: Second, the electrochemical behavior of the cobalt complex with the nonredox ligand, Na­[(L4 4–)­CoIII] (), shows that the first irreversible oxidation wave around 1.0 V vs NHE of Na­[(L1–3 4–)­CoIII] would be a ligand-centered proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) process. Interestingly, the electrochemical behavior of Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] in CH3CN/H2O was quite different. Upon gradual addition of water to an acetonitrile solution of Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII], the wave of ligand-centered oxidation at 0.49 V (vs Fc+/0) became irreversible, and the anodic current increased at 0.96 V, indicating an electrocatalytic oxidation behavior (Figures S17–S19). Due to the existence of H2O, the electrochemical behavior in buffer is different from the successive single electron and reversible redox behavior of [(L1 4–)­CoIII]−/[(L1 3–)­CoIII] and [(L1 3–)­CoIII]/[(L1 3–)­CoIV]+ displayed in acetonitrile. Upon oxidation of [(L1 4–)­CoIII]− in aqueous solution, the H2O molecule coordinates to the Co center, and the second proton-coupled electron transfer occurs simultaneously. The net result, formation of [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH], is equivalent to a combined “formal” (2e – + H+) oxidation and hydroxide binding. b shows the typical electrochemical behavior of both Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] and Na­[(L4 4–)­CoIII]. The former compound, which has a redox-active ligand (L1), displayed an irreversible oxidation wave around 1.0 V vs NHE, whereas for the latter with the non-redox-active ligand (L4), there is no electrochemical response around 1.0 V vs NHE. This result, together with the E–pH relationship, supports the idea that the first irreversible oxidation wave around 1.0 V vs NHE should be ascribed to the ligand-centered PCET oxidation of Na­[(L1–3 4–)­CoIII] with the help of H2O.

elements.content: Third, as shown by ESI-HRMS, the electrolysis at 1.2 V vs NHE caused the disappearance of the [(L1 4–)­CoIII]− peak (m/z = 429.0792, Figure S1) and the appearance of a new peak at m/z = 468.0886, which was designated as {[(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH] + H2O – H+}− (Figure S20). When [(L3 4–)­CoIII]− was treated with bulk electrolysis at 1.2 V vs NHE, the {[(L3 2–)­CoIII–OH] + H2O – H+}− peak (m/z = 531.0259, Figure S21) was also observed. Additionally, the electrolysis at 1.2 V vs NHE resulted in the oxidation of [(L1 4–)­CoIII]− to [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH], leading to a loss of intensity of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer band at 230 and 265 nm and increase of the MLCT band at 338 and 412 nm, as well as the bleach at 600 nm. These are probably due to the changes of d–d transition caused by the coordination environment transformed from a square to a quadrangular pyramid (Figure S22). X-ray photoelectron spectra () of [(L1 4–)­CoIII]− and the [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH] sample prepared by bulk electrolysis at 1.2 V vs NHE display very similar binding energies (780.3 eV for Co 2p3/2 and 795.5 eV for Co 2p1/2 of [(L1 4–)­CoIII]−; 780.8 eV for Co 2p3/2 and 796.3 eV for Co 2p1/2 of [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH], the weak yellow satellite peaks in both cobalt complexes’ Co 2p region probably were the shakeup lines of Co­(III)) consistent with Co­(III) oxidation state, indicating that the oxidation process at 1.2 V vs NHE happened on the ligand rather than Co­(III) center. In contrast, the O 1s region of the XPS spectrum of [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH] has an additional peak at 532.0 eV compared with the spectrum of [(L1 4–)­CoIII]− (530.9 and 532.2 eV for [(L1 4–)­CoIII]−; 531.2, 532.0, and 532.6 eV for [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH]). The binding energy peak at 532.0 eV is consistent with an OH group binding on the Co­(III). This matches well with the ligand-centered PCET 2e – oxidation involving a H2O, and [(L2–)­CoIII–OH] is the resulting resting state for water oxidation catalysis. From these data, it is clear that the ligand has undergone a PCET oxidation with H2O involved in the process ( and ).

The catalytic rates of these catalysts compare well with those reported k cat values around 1 s–1 for the single-site and polynuclear cobalt-based WOCs. elements.content: The catalytic peak current for water oxidation, i cat, varies linearly with the concentration of catalyst, Na­[(L1–3 4–)­CoIII], consistent with single-site cobalt catalysis (a and Figures S24 and S27). CV experiments were also performed in D2O (pD 7.0) phosphate buffer (Figure S30). Analysis of these data gave a kinetic isotope effect (KIE = k H2O/k D2O) of 2.0. Similar to the oxidation of water by RuVO, this kinetic isotope effect might be attributed to atom–proton transfer with O–O bond formation concerted with proton transfer to a proton acceptor, such as the base form of buffer. The electrochemical behaviors at different buffer concentrations were carried out at an adjusted ionic strength of I = 0.462 M by NaClO4 (Figures S31–S32), and the dependence of (i cat/i d)2 on phosphate concentrations (0–0.2 M) indicated that the buffer anion as proton acceptor could contribute to rate-limiting water nucleophilic attack of CoIVO. In terms of the available experimental results, the water oxidation mechanism in was proposed, in which the O–O bond formation step is analogous to the scheme proposed earlier for Ru polypyridyl catalysts. In this catalytic cycle, the resting state, [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH], was formed by a ligand-centered (2e – + H+) PCET oxidation, and a further PCET oxidation generated the catalytically active [(L1 2–)­CoIVO], which reacts with water by a rate-limiting O–O bond formation step to give an intermediate peroxide that could be further oxidized to release oxygen and close the cycle.
elements.clean_text:
Proposed Mechanism

The catalytic peak current for water oxidation, i cat, varies linearly with the concentration of catalyst, Na[(L1-3 4-)CoIII], consistent with single-site cobalt catalysis (a and Figures S24 and S27). CV experiments were also performed in D2O (pD 7.0) phosphate buffer (Figure S30). Analysis of these data gave a kinetic isotope effect (KIE = k H2O/k D2O) of 2.0. Similar to the oxidation of water by RuVO, this kinetic isotope effect might be attributed to atom-proton transfer with O-O bond formation concerted with proton transfer to a proton acceptor, such as the base form of buffer. The electrochemical behaviors at different buffer concentrations were carried out at an adjusted ionic strength of I = 0.462 M by NaClO4 (Figures S31-S32), and the dependence of (i cat/i d)2 on phosphate concentrations (0-0.2 M) indicated that the buffer anion as proton acceptor could contribute to rate-limiting water nucleophilic attack of CoIVO. In terms of the available experimental results, the water oxidation mechanism in  was proposed, in which the O-O bond formation step is analogous to the scheme proposed earlier for Ru polypyridyl catalysts. In this catalytic cycle, the resting state, [(L1 2-)CoIII-OH], was formed by a ligand-centered (2e - + H+) PCET oxidation, and a further PCET oxidation generated the catalytically active [(L1 2-)CoIVO], which reacts with water by a rate-limiting O-O bond formation step to give an intermediate peroxide that could be further oxidized to release oxygen and close the cycle.

elements.content: To disclose more details of the water oxidation catalytic cycle, in particular, the oxygen–oxygen bond formation event, density functional theory calculation was performed at the B3LYP-D3­(BJ)/6-311++G­(2df,2p)//B3LYP/6-31+G­(d,p) level. For the intermediates and the transition states, the solvation effect in water was taken into account by applying the SMD model during single-point energy calculation based on the gas-phase optimized structures. For the H2O molecule, proton, and sodium cation, the experimental solvation free energies in water were used.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

To disclose more details of the water oxidation catalytic cycle, in particular, the oxygen-oxygen bond formation event, density functional theory calculation was performed at the B3LYP-D3(BJ)/6-311++G(2df,2p)//B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) level. For the intermediates and the transition states, the solvation effect in water was taken into account by applying the SMD model during single-point energy calculation based on the gas-phase optimized structures. For the H2O molecule, proton, and sodium cation, the experimental solvation free energies in water were used.

elements.content: The model WOC employed in the DFT calculation is the triplet state complex Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] (). In aqueous solution, Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] combines one H2O molecule and undergoes PCET (H+ + 2e –) to give a triplet complex [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH], in which a hydroxyl group coordinates at the top of the complex and the redox-active tetraamido macrocyclic ligand was oxidized (L4– to L2–). The oxidation of the TAML moiety is clearly indicated by the changes in structural parameters: in the starting complex Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII], the C–C bond length of the benzene ring is evenly distributed (around 1.40 Å), and the N-aryl ring bond lengths are ca. 1.41 Å; in the complex [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH] after a PCET (H+ + 2e –), the C–C bonds in the former benzene ring are elongated and shortened alternately (1.42 and 1.38 Å, respectively), and the two N-aryl ring bonds are shortened to 1.36 Å. This is in accordance with the structural change in the oxidation of an o-diphenylene­dicarboxamido ligand to its benzoquinone­dicarboxamido form. The calculated natural bond orbital charge distributions of Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII] and [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH] also support the ligand-centered PCET because the charge on the ligand moiety changed from −1.885 to −0.482 during this process. The complex [(L1 2–)­CoIII–OH] is further oxidized through another PCET process to produce the proposed complex [(L1 2–)­CoIVO] ↔ [(L1 2–)­CoIII–O•]. Analysis of the calculated structure revealed that both the oxo moiety and the cobalt center bear significant spin densities. Therefore, the structure of the complex is better described as [(L1 2–)­CoIII–O•] (see the Supporting Information for details).

In aqueous solution, Na[(L1 4-)CoIII] combines one H2O molecule and undergoes PCET (H+ + 2e -) to give a triplet complex [(L1 2-)CoIII-OH], in which a hydroxyl group coordinates at the top of the complex and the redox-active tetraamido macrocyclic ligand was oxidized (L4- to L2-). The oxidation of the TAML moiety is clearly indicated by the changes in structural parameters: in the starting complex Na[(L1 4-)CoIII], the C-C bond length of the benzene ring is evenly distributed (around 1.40 Å), and the N-aryl ring bond lengths are ca. 1.41 Å; in the complex [(L1 2-)CoIII-OH] after a PCET (H+ + 2e -), the C-C bonds in the former benzene ring are elongated and shortened alternately (1.42 and 1.38 Å, respectively), and the two N-aryl ring bonds are shortened to 1.36 Å. This is in accordance with the structural change in the oxidation of an o-diphenylenedicarboxamido ligand to its benzoquinonedicarboxamido form. The calculated natural bond orbital charge distributions of Na[(L1 4-)CoIII] and [(L1 2-)CoIII-OH] also support the ligand-centered PCET because the charge on the ligand moiety changed from -1.885 to -0.482 during this process. The complex [(L1 2-)CoIII-OH] is further oxidized through another PCET process to produce the proposed complex [(L1 2-)CoIVO] ↔ [(L1 2-)CoIII-O⋅]. Analysis of the calculated structure revealed that both the oxo moiety and the cobalt center bear significant spin densities. Therefore, the structure of the complex is better described as [(L1 2-)CoIII-O⋅] (see the Supporting Information for details).

elements.content: The crucial oxygen–oxygen bond formation step follows a water nucleophilic attack (WNA) mechanism, in which the assistance of the buffer anion plays an important role. First, [(L1 2–)­CoIII–O•] binds with NaH2PO4 and a H2O molecule to give intermediate Int1, in which Na+ attached to one amide carbonyl group and the phosphate moiety, together with the H2O, complexed with Na+. This process is exergonic by 4.4 kcal/mol. Then the H2PO4 – anion assisted the nucleophilic attack of the H2O molecule at the oxo group of [(L1 2–)­CoIII–O•]: in the WNA transition state TS, the H2PO4 – anion binds to the oxo group by hydrogen bonding interaction (O···H distance = 1.74 Å), and it facilitates the attack of the oxygen in H2O to the oxo group (O···O distance = 1.83 Å) by abstracting a proton from H2O (). The WNA process has an activation free energy of 16.8 kcal/mol, and it turns out to be the rate-limiting step in the catalytic cycle. An alternative WNA pathway, which follows the established WNA model for the Fe–TAML complexes involving multiple H2O molecules, was also calculated. It was found that association of four H2O molecules with [(L1 2–)­CoIII–O•] is endogonic by 19.2 kcal/mol. In the WNA transition state TS′, these water molecules form a hydrogen bonding network, and the nucleophilic attack of one H2O to the oxo group (O···O distance = 1.78 Å) is facilitated by proton abstraction from another H2O molecule. However, this pathway has an overall activation free energy of 42.8 kcal/mol (from Int1), much higher than that of the dihydrophosphate-assisted pathway. The significant influence of H2PO4 – on the WNA process revealed by DFT calculation is in good agreement with the observed buffer effect.
elements.clean_text: The crucial oxygen-oxygen bond formation step follows a water nucleophilic attack (WNA) mechanism, in which the assistance of the buffer anion plays an important role. First, [(L1 2-)CoIII-O⋅] binds with NaH2PO4 and a H2O molecule to give intermediate Int1, in which Na+ attached to one amide carbonyl group and the phosphate moiety, together with the H2O, complexed with Na+. This process is exergonic by 4.4 kcal/mol. Then the H2PO4 - anion assisted the nucleophilic attack of the H2O molecule at the oxo group of [(L1 2-)CoIII-O⋅]: in the WNA transition state TS, the H2PO4 - anion binds to the oxo group by hydrogen bonding interaction (O⋅⋅⋅H distance = 1.74 Å), and it facilitates the attack of the oxygen in H2O to the oxo group (O⋅⋅⋅O distance = 1.83 Å) by abstracting a proton from H2O (). The WNA process has an activation free energy of 16.8 kcal/mol, and it turns out to be the rate-limiting step in the catalytic cycle. An alternative WNA pathway, which follows the established WNA model for the Fe-TAML complexes involving multiple H2O molecules, was also calculated. It was found that association of four H2O molecules with [(L1 2-)CoIII-O⋅] is endogonic by 19.2 kcal/mol. In the WNA transition state TS', these water molecules form a hydrogen bonding network, and the nucleophilic attack of one H2O to the oxo group (O⋅⋅⋅O distance = 1.78 Å) is facilitated by proton abstraction from another H2O molecule. However, this pathway has an overall activation free energy of 42.8 kcal/mol (from Int1), much higher than that of the dihydrophosphate-assisted pathway. The significant influence of H2PO4 - on the WNA process revealed by DFT calculation is in good agreement with the observed buffer effect.

elements.content: Both WNA pathways afford the quartet hydroperoxo cobalt­(II) complex, [(L1 2–)­CoII–OOH]. This species is oxidized to the superoxo cobalt­(III) complex [(L1 4–)­CoIII•O2] through a PCET process, with a calculated redox potential of 1.07 V at pH 7. Therefore, under the applied potential, this PCET process could occur directly. Finally, complex [(L1 4–)­CoIII•O2] releases an oxygen molecule and combines with Na+ to regenerate the WOC Na­[(L1 4–)­CoIII], which is dramatically exergonic by 25.3 kcal/mol. The overall driving force for water oxidation under the reference potential (1.4 V vs NHE) is calculated to be −54.8 kcal/mol in terms of Gibbs free energy, which is in good agreement with the theoretical value (−53.8 kcal/mol).
elements.clean_text: Both WNA pathways afford the quartet hydroperoxo cobalt(II) complex, [(L1 2-)CoII-OOH]. This species is oxidized to the superoxo cobalt(III) complex [(L1 4-)CoIII⋅O2] through a PCET process, with a calculated redox potential of 1.07 V at pH 7. Therefore, under the applied potential, this PCET process could occur directly. Finally, complex [(L1 4-)CoIII⋅O2] releases an oxygen molecule and combines with Na+ to regenerate the WOC Na[(L1 4-)CoIII], which is dramatically exergonic by 25.3 kcal/mol. The overall driving force for water oxidation under the reference potential (1.4 V vs NHE) is calculated to be -54.8 kcal/mol in terms of Gibbs free energy, which is in good agreement with the theoretical value (-53.8 kcal/mol).

elements.content: The DFT study supports the proposed mechanism for water oxidation by the Co–TAML complexes and reveals the molecular details in the oxygen–oxygen bond formation event, in which the phosphate-assisted water nucleophilic attack played a key role. The experimental observations, including the electrochemical properties, the water oxidation kinetics, and the buffer effect, could be rationalized by this mechanism.
elements.clean_text: The DFT study supports the proposed mechanism for water oxidation by the Co-TAML complexes and reveals the molecular details in the oxygen-oxygen bond formation event, in which the phosphate-assisted water nucleophilic attack played a key role. The experimental observations, including the electrochemical properties, the water oxidation kinetics, and the buffer effect, could be rationalized by this mechanism.

elements.content: In summary, we report a highly efficient electrocatalytic water oxidation in neutral aqueous solution (pH 7.0) by stable Co­(III) complexes bearing redox-active ligands. In addition, as CoO x is known to be highly active for water oxidation, the Co­(III) complex was conformed as a molecular catalyst under the working conditions. The catalytic cycle was examined in detail by the electrochemical method in combination with DFT calculations. As the working potential is increased, the Na­[(L4–)­Co­(III)] complex is first oxidized to [(L2–)­CoIII–OH] via ligand-centered proton-coupled electron transfer (2e – + H+) in the presence of water. The resulting resting state, [(L2–)­CoIII–OH], was further oxidized to [(L2–)­CoIVO], which could react with water to form an O–O bond with the help of a buffer anion. These results indicate that the interplay of ligand- and metal-centered redox activity is a benefit for water oxidation catalysts. We will focus our attention on developing new catalysts based on redox ligands and further understanding the structure–function–reactivity relationship of these redox ligands in water oxidation catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we report a highly efficient electrocatalytic water oxidation in neutral aqueous solution (pH 7.0) by stable Co(III) complexes bearing redox-active ligands. In addition, as CoO x  is known to be highly active for water oxidation, the Co(III) complex was conformed as a molecular catalyst under the working conditions. The catalytic cycle was examined in detail by the electrochemical method in combination with DFT calculations. As the working potential is increased, the Na[(L4-)Co(III)] complex is first oxidized to [(L2-)CoIII-OH] via ligand-centered proton-coupled electron transfer (2e - + H+) in the presence of water. The resulting resting state, [(L2-)CoIII-OH], was further oxidized to [(L2-)CoIVO], which could react with water to form an O-O bond with the help of a buffer anion. These results indicate that the interplay of ligand- and metal-centered redox activity is a benefit for water oxidation catalysts. We will focus our attention on developing new catalysts based on redox ligands and further understanding the structure-function-reactivity relationship of these redox ligands in water oxidation catalysis.
